data.value: define the errorbar sizes. By default, this draws the data markers/lines as well the errorbars. Use fmt='none' to draw errorbars without any data markers.
If given, the following parameters also accept a string
All other keyword arguments are passed on to the
call drawing the markers. For example, this code makes big red squares with thick green edges:

x, y, yerr = rand(3, 10)
errorbar(x, y, yerr, marker='s', mfc='red',
         mec='green', ms=20, mew=4)
are aliases for the longer property names,
Valid kwargs for the marker properties are:

Properties: agg_filter: a filter function, which takes a (m, n, 3) float array and a dpi value, and returns a (m, n, 3) array and two offsets from the bottom left corner of the image alpha: scalar or None animated: bool antialiased or aa: bool clip_box:
clip_on: bool clip_path: Patch or (Path, Transform) or None color or c: color dash_capstyle:

or {'miter', 'round', 'bevel'} dashes: sequence of floats (on/off ink in points) or (None, None) data: (2, N) array or two 1D arrays drawstyle or ds: {'default', 'steps', 'steps-pre', 'steps-mid', 'steps-post'}, default: 'default' figure:

fillstyle: {'full', 'left', 'right', 'bottom', 'top', 'none'} gapcolor: color or None gid: str in_layout: bool label: object linestyle or ls: {'-', '--', '-.', ':', '', (offset, on-off-seq), ...} linewidth or lw: float marker: marker style string,

markeredgecolor or mec: color markeredgewidth or mew: float markerfacecolor or mfc: color markerfacecoloralt or mfcalt: color markersize or ms: float markevery: None or int or (int, int) or slice or list[int] or float or (float, float) or list[bool] mouseover: bool path_effects:
picker: float or callable[[Artist, Event], tuple[bool, dict]] pickradius: unknown rasterized: bool sketch_params: (scale: float, length: float, randomness: float) snap: bool or None solid_capstyle:
or {'miter', 'round', 'bevel'} transform: unknown url: str visible: bool xdata: 1D array ydata: 1D array zorder: float
scalar: Symmetric +/- values for all data points.
shape(N,): Symmetric +/-values for each data point.
shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row   contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper   errors.
for an example on the usage of

children.type_: float or array-like, shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional

data.value: The format for the data points / data lines. See
Use 'none' (case insensitive) to plot errorbars without any data markers.
The color of the errorbar lines.  If None, use the color of the line connecting the markers.
The linewidth of the errorbar lines. If None, the linewidth of the current style is used.
The length of the error bar caps in points.
An alias to the keyword argument
). This setting is a more sensible name for the property that controls the thickness of the error bar cap in points. For backwards compatibility, if
are given, then they will over-ride
. This may change in future releases.
If True, will plot the errorbars above the plot symbols. Default is below.
These arguments can be used to indicate that a value gives only upper/lower limits.  In that case a caret symbol is used to indicate this.
-arguments may be scalars, or array-likes of the same length as
.  To use limits with inverted axes,
.  Note the tricky parameter names: setting e.g.
to True means that the y-value is a
limit of the True value, so, only an
draws error bars on a subset of the data.
=N draws error bars on the points (x[::N], y[::N]).

=(start, N) draws error bars on the points (x[start::N], y[start::N]). e.g. errorevery=(6, 3) adds error bars to the data at (x[6], x[9], x[12], x[15], ...). Used to avoid overlapping error bars when two series share x-axis values.
instance of x, y plot markers and/or line.
instances of the error bar caps.
with the horizontal and   vertical error ranges.
Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers with attached errorbars.
